attributes.title: Communicating a range of possible values in an icon array in the context of a genetic report
attributes.description:
Icon arrays are a form of visualisation commonly used to illustrate risk probabilities as they apply to a population. For example, if roughly 12 out of 100 individuals undergoing a particular medical procedure can be expected to have a particular outcome, this can be illustrated on an icon array by highlighting 12 out of 100 icons (people, circles, boxes, etc.) in one colour, and the other 88 in another. 

While icon arrays are much used in healthcare visualisations due to the fact that one does not need to understand percentages or manipulate abstract numbers to get a sense of one’s risk at a glance, it is unclear how well they can communicate the concept of a range of possible risk probabilities. For example, in the East Midlands and East of England, the risk of cancer for carriers of BRCA pathogenic variants is commonly communicated as a range (e.g., 65%-79%) due to statistical uncertainty around the true level of risk. 

Our key hypotheses concern the degree to which different ways of communicating a range of risk probabilities are understood in this context. Specifically, we wish to test whether lay participants’ recall of the increased risk that accompanies a pathogenic BRCA variant is substantially improved (or impaired) by the inclusion of an icon array, using any of three different approaches to illustrating a risk range.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Communicating a range of possible values in an icon array in the context of a genetic report

other.value:
Subgroup analyses: The analyses described in the "Analyses" section will also be run separately on: 
- the subgroup of individuals who score in the bottom half of the sample with respect to objective health literacy; 
- the subgroup of individuals who score in the bottom half of the sample with respect to subjective health literacy; and
- the subgroup of individuals who score in the bottom half of the sample with respect to numeracy.

Other analyses:
If recall is not significantly different between the control group vs. the arrow, shaded, or gradient conditions, we will also perform equivalence tests using the 'two-one-sided t-tests' procedure to test whether there is support for the absence of a true effect (i.e., a true effect smaller than the smallest effect size of interest, d = .23).

Exploratory analyses will be conducted to investigated effects of arrangement of the icon arrays in a tabular vs. nontabular format. For example, if differences in recall are found between the control condition vs. the arrow, shaded, or gradient conditions, exploratory analyses may be conducted to investigate whether these differences seem independent of the arrangement of the icon arrays in a tabular vs. nontabular format.

We are also collecting exploratory data on the following, which may be explored further in exploratory analyses: 
attitudes towards the risk information, subjective understanding of the risk information, subjective description of the degree of risk, recall of exact numbers mentioned in the report, and subjective recall.

We are also collecting data on potential mediators and moderators, which may be controlled for or explored in further exploratory analyses: Numeracy; subjective and objective health literacy; age; education level; gender; experience with cancer or BRCA testing.

sample.value: Assuming population parameters similar to those estimated by Recchia et al. (2020) with the original gist comprehension measure (from which the current DVs were adapted), and treating the effect size observed in that study (d = .23) as the smallest effect size of interest, we require 1300 participants total to have 95% power to detect differences between treatment groups and control groups using Dunnett’s procedure (DunnettTests library in R). This sample size is also adequate to achieve 80% power on the equivalence tests mentioned later in this preregistration.

analyses.value: The primary analysis will be conducted with one-way ANOVAs (unless data violates ANOVA assumptions to such a degree that ANOVAs would be inappropriate, in which case non-parametric alternatives may be employed), with Dunnett’s test used to test for differences between the control condition vs. the arrow, shaded, and gradient conditions.

outliers.value: Participants who do not complete the study will be excluded.

dependent.value:
The main DVs are three measures of gist recall, investigating whether, after looking at this array in the context of the full genetic report, people correctly recall that:
- people with this gene alteration are more likely to get breast cancer than ovarian cancer;
- people with this gene alteration are more likely to get breast cancer than members of the general population are;
- people with this gene alteration are more likely to get ovarian cancer than members of the general population are.

The gist recall measures are adapted from the gist comprehension measure used in Recchia et al. (2020), modified to measure recall with respect to the three bullet points above. 

Each of the three measures is effectively a test of whether people correctly recall that the probability of X is greater than the probability of Y. Each measure has a maximum score of 4 points. The first two points come from multiple-choice questions asking participants to compare the probabilities of X and Y; any response which acknowledges that X is more probable than Y is counted as correct. Participants are also asked to estimate the probabilities of X and Y as frequencies (out of a constant denominator); responses that estimate a higher frequency for X are also awarded one point. Finally, participants are asked to estimate the probabilities of X and Y as percentages; responses that estimate a higher percentage for X are awarded one point.

We will measure objective health literacy, subjective health literacy, and numeracy for purposes of subgroup analysis, using the UK version of Newest Vital Sign (Rowlands et al 2013), subscale 9 of the Health Literacy Questionnaire (Osborne et al 2013), and the Berlin Numeracy Test (Cokely et al 2012), respectively.

The accuracy of the percentages and frequencies produced by participants (i.e., verbatim recall) will also be investigated, but only in exploratory analyses.
 
Recchia, G., van der Bles, A. M., & Freeman, A. L. J. (2020). PREDICT: the potential pitfalls of visualisations of risk. [Published abstract, poster]. UK Interdisciplinary Breast Cancer Symposium 2020. Breast Cancer Research and Treatment. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10549-019-05514-3

Rowlands, G., Khazaezadeh, N., Oteng-Ntim, E., Seed, P., Barr, S., & Weiss, B. D. (2013). Development and validation of a measure of health literacy in the UK: the newest vital sign. BMC Public Health, 13(1), 116.

Osborne, R. H., Batterham, R. W., Elsworth, G. R., Hawkins, M., & Buchbinder, R. (2013). The grounded psychometric development and initial validation of the Health Literacy Questionnaire (HLQ). BMC Public Health, 13(1), 658.

Cokely, E. T., Galesic, M., Schulz, E., Ghazal, S., & Garcia-Retamero, R. (2012). Measuring risk literacy: The Berlin numeracy test. Judgment and Decision making.

conditions.value:
This will be a between-subjects design with 4 primary conditions. Participants will view a genetic report that contains the information they will be asked to recall in a textual format; furthermore, the report they view will either have an icon array that displays ranges using arrows, an icon array that displays ranges using shaded icons, an icon array that displays ranges using a gradient, or no icon array (control). Examples of each kind of icon array can be found in image files attached to this OSF project.

To facilitate exploratory investigations of whether any observed differences are due to the particular choice of stimulus, participants in the non-control will be further randomized as to whether the icon arrays on the report they are shown appear in a tabular or nontabular format. Examples of both formats can be found in image files attached to this OSF project.

For example, if roughly 12 out of 100 individuals undergoing a particular medical procedure can be expected to have a particular outcome, this can be illustrated on an icon array by highlighting 12 out of 100 icons (people, circles, boxes, etc.) in one colour, and the other 88 in another.

attributes.title: Probing ovulatory cycle shifts in women’s preferences for men’s behaviors
attributes.description: The existence of ovulatory cycle shifts in women’s mate preferences has been discussed controversially. There is evidence that naturally cycling women in their fertile phase, compared to their luteal phase, evaluate specific behavioral cues in men as more attractive for sexual relationships. However, recent research has cast doubt on these findings. We addressed this debate in a large, pre-registered within-subject study including salivary hormone measures and luteinizing hormone tests. One-hundred-fifty-seven female participants rated natural videos of 70 men in dyadic intersexual interactions on sexual and long-term attractiveness. Multilevel comparisons across two ovulatory cycles indicated that women’s mate preferences for men’s behaviors did not shift across the cycle, neither for competitive, nor for courtship behavior. Hormone levels and relationship status did not affect these results. Hormonal mechanisms and implications for estrus theories are discussed.

summary.value: This is a registration of the Open Material files for the paper "Probing ovulatory cycle shifts in women's preferences for men's behaviors", by Stern, Gerlach and Penke, to appear in Psychological Science in 2020.

attributes.title: Effects of Sex Steroids on the Sporting Performance of Transgender Individuals, with a focus on bone health, lung function and skeletal muscle physiology. A question of advantage or disadvantage?
attributes.description:
In 2015, the IOC allowed Transgender Athletes to compete after 1 year of HRT and without SRS (1). A primary concern is that TW develop permanent physiological features that give them a performance advantage over cis-women. Prior research has focused primarily on observational studies with no or limited evidence of change in body composition (2) and bone (3). There is also a lack of data on MTFT lung function. The aim: track TW individuals during their HRT cycle to quantify changes in body composition, bone health, muscle fibre physiology and lung function to further clarify if TW individuals retain an advantage.
Glossary of Terms
IOC: international Olympic Committee
HRT: Hormone Replacement Therapy
SRS: Sexual Reassignment Surgery
TW: Transwomen

References
1.	J. Gleaves and T. Lehrbach, “Beyond fairness: the ethics of inclusion for transgender and intersex athletes,” Journal of the Philosophy of Sport, vol. 43, no. 2, pp. 311–326, Aug. 2015.
2.	G. T. Sjoen, S. Weyers, Y. Taes, B. Lapauw, K. Toye, S. Goemaere, and J.-M. Kaufman, “Prevalence of Low Bone Mass in Relation to Estrogen Treatment and Body Composition in Male-to-Female Transsexual Persons,” J Clin Densitom, vol. 12, no. 3, pp. 306–313, Jul. 2009.
3.	N. Singh-Ospina, S. Maraka, R. Rodriguez-Gutierrez, C. Davidge-Pitts, T. B. Nippoldt, L. J. Prokop, and M. H. Murad, “Effect of Sex Steroids on the Bone Health of Transgender Individuals: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis,” The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism, vol. 102, no. 11, pp. 3904–3913, Sep. 2017

q1.value: Blair Hamilton, Fergus Guppy, Yannis Pitsiladis

q2.value: Transwomens sporting performance is adversely affected by the administration of Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT), in contrast, Transmens sporting performance is positively affected by the administration of HRT.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will investigate the changes that occur to sporting performance including muscle fibre physiology during 20 TM and 20 TW transitions. Once recruited, participants will be required to report to the School of Pharmacy and Bi-molecular Sciences, University of Brighton on 4 occasions, 2 prior (6 and 3 weeks) and 3 after (3, 6 and 12 months) starting HRT.  On each visit participants will undergo assessment of bone health and body composition using DXA, muscle biopsy as well as lung function tests using basic spirometry and VO2 Max testing on a cycle ergo-meter

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This research is a unique collaboration with the Tavistock Centre in Hammersmith, London, England (https://tavistockandportman.nhs.uk). This research aims to follow 40 young individuals over the age of 18 who are being treated at GIC and are either transitioning from male to female or female to male and have a BMI of  between 18.5 - 24.99 kg/m2.

Visits to the laboratory: Once recruited, participants will be required to report to the School of Pharmacy and Bimolecular Sciences, University of Brighton on 5 occasions, 2 prior (6 and 3 weeks) and 3 after (3, 6 and 12 months) starting HRT.  On each visit participants will undergo assessment of bone health and body composition using DXA scanning. All subjects will be asked to volunteer for a follow up study some 18-24 months after starting HRT

q11.value: Our target sample size is 30 participants (15TW and 15TM). We will attempt to recruit 40 (20 TW and 20 TM) participants assuming all will not complete the study.

question.value: The Variable manipulated will be the subjects hormones through their gender affirming hormone replacement therapy for both cohorts, Testosterone therapy for Trans-men and estrogen therapy coupled with testosterone suppression for Trans-women.  The 5 times of testing and measurement will be 3 weeks prior to administration, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and 12 months post administration.

Body Composition and Bone Mass Assessment: 
Total and regional body composition was estimated by DXA (Horizon W, Hologic Inc., Connecticut, USA), with images analysed using preinstalled software for the calculation of lean and fat mass (kg) as well as the percentage of fat mass. Due to the inbuilt analysis assumptions regarding the measurement of head composition, whole body less head (WBLH) data will be used. Precision of operator repeated measurements ranges from 0.26-1.69% for total mass, 1.36-2.78% for fat mass and 0.77-1.90% for lean mass, respectively. Areal BMD (g·cm-2), BMC (g) and bone mineral area (cm2) will be measured in the lumbar spine (L1-L4) and the left proximal femur by DXA and analysis conducted using the preinstalled machine software. Total lumbar spine, proximal femur, femoral neck and Ward's triangle will be analysed separately, with all scanning and analysis conducted by the same operator, with precision of repeated measurements ranging from 1.51-3.15% for BMD

Physical Activity Assessment: 
The International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) and smart-watch technology will be used to estimate the time spent on various domains of physical activity. 
Lung Function Testing:
Basic spirometry measures will be taken, such as Forced expiratory volume (FEV) and Forced expiratory volume (FEV1) in one second will be taken before the participant undertakes stationary bike VO2 max testing on a cycle ergometer.

Muscle biopsy:
 muscle fibres will be biopsied from the vastus lateralis (outer thigh), a small local anaesthetic will be given so a ~0.1g sample of muscle can be taken to establish certain muscle fibre parameters e.g., myonuclei number, satellite cell number and fibre cross sectional area (CSA).

Changes in body composition, lung function and muscle physiology will be analysed using a repeated measures ANOVA (RMANOVA) using standard statistical packages (i.e., R), using baseline measures as a co-variate in order to minimize the effect of differences in size on changes in fat mass, lean mass and BMD.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA  suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct

q21.value: If a subject does not complete baseline testing (3 weeks prior), 1 year testing and at least one test in between (6 weeks, 3 months and 6 months), that subject will not be included in the analysis.

subjects.text: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies

summary.value:
Abstract
Background: Research outcome data is commonly collected using postal questionnaires; however, poor response can introduce bias and reduce statistical power. Text messaging is simple, cost-effective, and can be customised to the individual. Personalised, reminder text messages may improve response rates.

Methods: A two-arm, parallel group ‘Study within a Trial’ (SWAT) was embedded within the Occupational Therapist Intervention Study (OTIS), a randomised controlled trial of a home assessment for falls prevention in older people.  OTIS participants who provided a mobile phone number were randomly allocated (1:1) to receive either a personalised text message (Title, Surname, plus York Trials Unit (YTU) text) or the standard YTU text alone, prior to receiving their four-month post-randomisation follow-up postal questionnaire. The primary outcome measure was the proportion of participants who returned the questionnaire. Secondary outcomes were: time to response, completeness of response, requirement of a reminder letter, and cost-effectiveness. Binary data were compared using logistic regression and time to response by Cox Proportional Hazards regression.

Results: A total of 403 participants were randomised: 201 to the personalised text; and 202 to the standard text.  Of the 283 participants included in the final analysis, 278 (98.2%) returned their questionnaire; 136 (97.8%) for the personalised text versus 142 (98.6%) for the standard text (adjusted odds ratio 0.64, 95% CI 0.10 to 3.88, p=0.63).  The median time to response was nine days in both groups.  In total, 271 (97.5%) participants returned a complete questionnaire; 133 (97.8%) in the personalised text versus 138 (97.2%) for the standard text.  Twenty one reminder letters were sent overall. The additional cost of personalised text messages was £0.04 per participant retained.

Conclusions: Personalised texts were not superior to standard texts in any outcome assessed in our study. Further SWATs are needed to perform a meta-analysis and obtain more evidence.

Registration: ISRCTN22202133; SWAT 35

Keywords: SWAT, Randomised Controlled Trial, personalised, SMS text, postal questionnaire, reminder

Secondary outcomes were: time to response, completeness of response, requirement of a reminder letter, and cost-effectiveness. Binary data were compared using logistic regression and time to response by Cox Proportional Hazards regression.

Results: A total of 403 participants were randomised: 201 to the personalised text; and 202 to the standard text.  Of the 283 participants included in the final analysis, 278 (98.2%) returned their questionnaire; 136 (97.8%) for the personalised text versus 142 (98.6%) for the standard text (adjusted odds ratio 0.64, 95% CI 0.10 to 3.88, p=0.63).  The median time to response was nine days in both groups.  In total, 271 (97.5%) participants returned a complete questionnaire; 133 (97.8%) in the personalised text versus 138 (97.2%) for the standard text.  Twenty one reminder letters were sent overall. The additional cost of personalised text messages was £0.04 per participant retained.

Conclusions: Personalised texts were not superior to standard texts in any outcome assessed in our study. Further SWATs are needed to perform a meta-analysis and obtain more evidence.

Registration: ISRCTN22202133; SWAT 35

Keywords: SWAT, Randomised Controlled Trial, personalised, SMS text, postal questionnaire, reminder

attributes.title: Research Focus: Distorted information
attributes.description:
In 2020 the new coronavirus COVID-19 spread around the globe, leading to a pandemic which killed thousands of people across countries. Multiple countries implemented unprecedent policies to stop its spread including harsh demands for physical distancing and increased hygienic behaviors. Although COVID-19 was not the first pandemic in human history, it was the first within the digital society and the world health organization (WHO) rapidly warned that the pandemic was accompanied by a large-scale ‘infodemic’—“an over-abundance of information –some accurate and some not –that makes it hard for people to find trustworthy sources and reliable guidance” (Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCov), 2020). Concerns were large that citizens confrontation with ‘polluted’ (Phillips & Milner, forthcomming) misleading and purposefully distorted information in this environment could impair the global fight against the pandemic. 
The current study addresses this concern. Using the differential susceptibility to media effects model (Valkenburg & Peter, 2013) as theoretical framework and a random-quota survey of the German population as data base, we examined the role of socio-demographics, citizens generalized ideological attitudes (right-wing authoritarianism, conspiracy mentality, intolerance for uncertainty, extreme political leanings), their trust in information authorities, intolerance of uncertainty, as well as the influence of their personal involvement and news media use for their emotional response to the situation (corona-related state uncertainty), their exposure to and belief in distorted news about COVID-19 (medical and conspiracy-theoretical falsehoods), and their COVID-19 related behavior. 
Parts of the study formed the Master-thesis of the second author (Lara Kuhfeldt), which studied the role of uncertainty for conspiracy theories around the COVID-19 crisis. In consequence, predictions related to intolerance for uncertainty, trust in society and corona-related uncertainty are not entailed in this pre-registration but can be found in the sub-project "uncertainty and conspiracy theories".

q2.value:
The overarching theoretical framework of our model is the differential susceptibility to media effects model (Valkenburg & Peter, 2013, p. 226). The DSMM provides a comprehensive formalization for media effects on individual recipients. The DSMM’s basic assumption is that media effects can be understood as a combination of conditional and indirect effects. Conditional effects emerge from three types of so-called susceptibility variables: individual’s disposition (e.g., their attitudes or personality), their developmental state (e.g. whether the recipient is a child), and their social situation. On the one hand, susceptibility variables predict media use. For instance, individuals with a fundamentalist (Bronstein et al. 2019) or conservative disposition engage more actively with distorted news (Guess et al., 2020). On the other hand, susceptibility variables moderate recipients’ responses to media content. For instance, prejudice decreases internal resistance against stereotypical news (Arendt, 2016). Indirect effects are driven by recipients’ responses to media content. The DSMM distinguishes three response types: cognitive (e.g., internal counterarguing), emotional (e.g., anger), and, closely related, “excitatory” responses (e.g., a faster heartbeat). The survey combines the data collection for different research foci around this general model. We will partially address the different research foci in separate papers.
Research focus 1 (R1): Which factors predict alternative and non-traditional news use during the pandemic?
Hypotheses and Research questions for R1: 
H.1.1 Distrust increases the turning towards alternative news sources (Tsfati, 2010; Tsfati & Peri, 2006): 
(a)	People with low levels of trust will use more alternative news websites. 
(b)	People with low levels of trust will use more non-traditional news gateways.
H.1.2. Conspiracy mentality increases the turning towards alternative news sources with (Castanho Silva et al., 2017)
(c)	People with high levels of conspiracy mentality will use more alternative news websites. 
(d)	People with high levels of conspiracy mentality will use more non-traditional news gateways.
H.1.3. RWA increases the turning towards right-wing and foreign-based alternative news sources (Lavine et al., 2005)
H.1.4. Extreme political leanings increase the turning towards ideology-consistent alternative news sources  (Müller & Schulz, 2019) 
H.1.5. Extreme political leanings increase the turning towards non-traditional news gateways.
Research focus 2 (R2): Which factors predict exposure to distorted news surrounding COVID-19?
H.2.1. Using non-traditional news gateways is associated with a larger exposure to distorted news about COVID-19 (Guess et al., 2020)
H.2.2. Using alternative news media is associated with a larger exposure to distorted news about COVID-19.
Research focus 3 (R3): Who believes in distorted news about COVID-19?
RQ 3.1) How credible are distorted as compared to factual news about COVID-19? 
H3.1. People who have seen distorted news before, assign them a higher believability (Pennycook et al., 2017)
H.3.2 Conspiracy mentality will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People scoring higher on conspiracy mentality will belief more in distorted news (Halpern et al., 2019). 
H.3.3 RWA will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People scoring higher on RWA will belief more in distorted news (Frischlich et al. under review)
H3.4 Media trust will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People who trust the (mainstream) media belief less in distorted news (Zimmermann & Kohring, 2020). 
Research focus 4 (R4): Who amplifies distorted news about COVID-19?
H 4.1. Higher believe in distorted news predicts higher amplification intentions. 
H 4.2 Higher believe in of distorted news predicts more ‘infodemic’ behavior.  
H 4.3. Participants report higher amplification intentions for distorted news that match their attitudes. 
1.	Higher levels of conspiracy mentality predict higher amplifications intentions for distorted news. 
2.	This association is stronger for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news compared to distorted news without conspiracy-theoretical elements.  
3.	Higher levels of right-wing authoritarianism (RWA) predict higher amplification intentions for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news. 
4.	Lower levels of media trust predict higher amplification intentions for distorted news with and without conspiracy theoretical elements.
H 4.3. Distrustful participants report more pollution behaviors. 
1.	Higher levels of conspiracy mentality predict more infodemic behaviors.
2.	Lower levels of trust predict more infodemic behaviors.
H 4.3. Users of alternative news media report higher amplification intentions for distorted news about COVID-19. 
H 4.3 Users of alternative news media report more ‘infodemic’ behaviors. 
Research focus 5: Behavioral consequences of the believe in distorted news about COVID-19.
H.5.1: Believe in distorted news will be associated negatively with healthy behavior.
H.5.2: Believe in of distorted news will be associated positively with dysfunctional behavior.
Research Focus 6 (R6): Indirect Effects of the Exposure to Distorted News on Behavior
H 6.1 We expect that the relationships between exposure and healthy behavior will be mediated by the believability of distorted news (indirect effect)
H 6.2 We expect that the relationships between exposure and dysfunctional behavior will be mediated by the believability of distorted news (indirect effect).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The study employs a unifactorial within-subjects design with four levels (news type: factual, distorted(medical), distorted(conspirational), placebo).

q7.value: Participants see the headlines in randomized order using the SoSci survey function of displaying pages in a random order.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data. As the date of submission of this research plan, the research team did not see any data. Data collection started the day before the pre-registration (26th of March 2020) and is expected to be completed at the 2nd of April.

question.value: Data collection will be conducted via the online access panel by Rispondi. The data is representative for the German population between 18 and 89 in terms of age, gender, and German region. Participants are payed for their participation following the Rispondi guidelines.

q11.value: We will analyze the data of all participants that did not match any of the exclusion criteria described below. We expect that at least 900 individuals will be included (i.e. we expect a quality fail of not more than 10%)

question.value:
We created a set of 11 news headlines: Six of them were distorted news and had been officially debunked by German fact-checking organizations or scientific publications. Three of this distorted news headlines promote conspiracy-theories (“US-special forces use Corona as a distraction to contract their troops at European airports for a secret invasion”, “Corona: A plot to fight overpopulation”, and “Corona-virus: Secret plan of the government detected”), the other three promote false medical information: “Anti-Corona: When taking in, chlorine oxide helps”, “toilet paper from China: Contaminated with corona”, and “Cocaine helps against the corona-virus”). 
Another three headlines were published news by a large-scale German newspaper, Spiegel online. They were selected to refer to societal consequences of the virus (“Epidemiologists recommend long-term restrictions of public life”, “Italy prolongs curfew”, and “Because of the pandemic: US president Trump wants to activate war-economy law”).
Finally, we also included two placebo headlines to account for false memory effects (Allcott & Gentzkow, 2017; Zimmermann & Kohring, 2020). The two placebo headlines reflected both medical (“Dr. Spitzer: Fight corona with kale”) and conspiracy-theoretical (“Corona: “China’s attempt to restrict European civil rights”) ideas. Order of headlines was randomized.

Socio-demographic data: 
o	Current German federal state in which the person lives
o	gender (male, female, diverse)
o	age
o	whether German was the participants’ first language (yes/no)
o	Which educational level they had completed
•	Political leaning (1=”right-wing”, 10=”left-wing”, see Wasmer et al. (1996)). 
Media use:
•	Traditional news gateways used in the last week (Newman et al., 2019): TV, radio, print (weekly- or daily newspaper), online broadcasters, and online newspapers. Multiple answers were possible.
•	Non-traditional news gateways: From the Reuters digital news report (Newman et al., 2019): Social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter), other online news. In addition: Self-developed items tackling “Instant messengers (like WhatsApp/Telegram/Facebook Messenger)”, “YouTube”, “People I know personally (e.g. friends and family)”, “groups within social networks”, and “podcasts”. Multiple answers were possible. 
•	Intentional news avoidance: “I avoid the active consumption of news” (Skovsgaard & Andersen, 2020). 
•	Alternative news media use: Relying on the Reuters digital news survey (Newman et al., 2019), we asked participants which alternative news sources they had used in the last week. As we aimed of balance in terms of political leaning of the outlets, participants reported for six outlets whether they had used them in the last week: Indy media and Junge Welt as left-leaning sources, Politically incorrect news (PI-news), and Junge Freiheit as right-wing leaning sources, Russia today and epoch times as sources with foreign roots. Furthermore, we asked for “other” alternative news sources and participants were able to state that they did not use any ‘alternative news source’. Multiple answers were possible. 
•	Covid-19 news. In the next step, we asked participants for their main news source for information about “the corona-virus”.  The items were largely the same as for news sources, but we added options for “alternative news sources (e.g. PI-news, Indymedia, RT)”, “official sources (e.g. ministries, the Robert-Koch Institute)”, as well as one attention item “I did not witness news about the corona-virus”, and one miscellaneous option. Here, only one option could be selected. 
Trust
•	We measured trust in the established or ‘mainstream’ media with three items, (“The established media report in a balanced manner”, “the reports of the established media are precise”, “the established media depict events fully”) created by Blöbaum (2018) and answered on a 5-point scale (1= “not applying”, 5 = “fully applying”).
•	We measured trust in the political system with two self-created questions: “How much do you trust the German government in handling the current situation around the corona-virus?” and “how much do you trust the health-politic of your country to deal with the corona virus SARS-CoV-2?” – both answered on a 5-point scale (1= “not at all”, 5 = “very much”).
Personal involvement
•	To account for recipients personal involvement with the corona-pandemic, we asked whether they or a close-other belonged to a risk-group following the guidelines by the German Robert-Koch institute (yes, no, I don’t want to answer), and whether they were in personal contact with the virus by asking them whether they were “tested positively for the virus”, “were in official quarantine due to the corona-virus”, or “whether a close other had been tested positively”. Multiple answers were possible. 
Uncertainty due to Corona
•	We measured corona-related uncertainty with a single item: “I feel uncertain due to the current situation related to the corona-virus” (1 = “fully disagree”, 5 = “fully agree”). 
 
Response to the news headlines
•	After each headline, participants rated its familiarity, believability and their amplification intentions. All items were answered on 5-point scales (1 = “absolutely not applying”, 5 = “fully applying”)
•	Familiarity was measured via a single recall statement: “I remember that I have seen this news or have discussed about this news”.
•	Believability was measured with two items: “This news is credible” and “This news is certainly true”. 
•	Amplification intentions were measured with three items: “I would evaluate this news with a ‘like’”, “I would forward this news”, and “I would like to know more about this news”
Corona-motivated behavior
•	Healthy behavior: Three of the behaviors reflected recommendations by the World-health organization and the German Robert-Koch institute (“I have washed or disinfected my hand and/or objects mor often”, “I have cancelled a meeting with friends at home”, and “I have physically distanced from people, I usually shake hands with or hug”).
•	Dysfunctional behavior was measured with two items: “I have bought more supplies than usual”, and “I thought to myself: Now more than ever: Better sick now before intensive care units are overburdened” 
•	‘infodemic behavior’: was measured with two items: “I doubted the ‘mainstream’ media reports”, “I forwarded WhatsApp messages where I did not know the original sender in person”.
For all behaviors, participants were asked how often they executed them due to the “corona-pandemic” (1 = ”never”, 5 = “always”).
 
Attitudes
•	We measured RWA with the nine-item scale by Beierlein et al. (2014). 
•	We measured Conspiracy mentality with the 5-item scale by Bruder et al. (2013)
Personality
•	We measured intolerance for uncertainty with 9-items by Carleton et al. (2007). 
Self-estimated quality/data retraction option
To allow for data retraction, we included a self-estimated quality question. Participants were asked to select between “I have answered the questionnaire as good as possible, although I might have been uncertain once in a while. My data can be used” versus “I answered the questionnaire only for interest, my data should not be used”.

•	Socio-demographics: We will calculate dummy-coded variables representing male gender, residence in the former Eastern versus Western-parts of Germany and higher-education (corresponding to high-school and higher). 
•	Political extremity: We will calculate a variable representing extremity of political attitudes be recoding a political leaning of 5 and 6 as zero, and political-leanings of 4 and 7 as 1, of 3 and 8 as 2, of 2 and 9 as 3, of 1 and 10 as 4, respectively.
•	Media use: To represent traditional news gateways, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the traditional news sources in the last week. To represent non-traditional news gateways, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the non-traditional news sources in the last week. To represent alternative news use, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the alternative news (including “other alternative news”) in the last week. To represent “dark social” use, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants accessed news via Instant messengers, social media groups, or family and friends. 
•	Personal involvement: We will calculate a dummy-coded variable representing whether participants have a direct involvement (being either a risk-group, quarantined or infected) or a secondary involvement (a close other being a risk-group or infected). No involvement will serve as reference category
•	Response to the news stimuli: We will calculate means per headline and scale (believe in news headlines, amplification intentions). We will further calculate means per item across the three distorted conspiracy-theoretical headlines, the three false but not conspiracy-theoretical headlines, the two placebo headlines and the three real-headlines and calculate an aggregation of these items per headline type. 
•	Recall of distorted, placebo, and factual news: Following the procedure by Zimmermann and Kohring (2020), we will calculate dummy-variables representing the recall of distorted, real, and placebo news. 
•	Susceptibility factors: Conspiracy mentality, intolerance for uncertainty, and RWA will be aggregated to mean values after checking their internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha). 
•	Behaviors. Depending on the normality of the distribution, we will either calculate means or medians to aggregate the three healthy behaviors, the two dysfunctional behaviors and the two pollution behaviors.

Research focus 1:
 Alternative and non-traditional news use during the pandemic
For testing H 1.1 – H 1.5 we will calculate two logistic regression analyses using (a) the dummy-coded use of alternative news sources and (b) dummy-coded non-traditional news gateways. In these analyses, RWA; conspiracy mentality, political extremity and trust will serve as predictors. We will enter all susceptibility variables simultaneously. We will re-run the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and overall news use by using a hierarchical approach in which socio-demographic variables are entered in the first block, traditional news gateways in the second, and susceptibility variables in the last block. 

Research focus 2: Exposure to distorted news
For testing H.2.1 and H.2.2., we will calculate a linear regression in which recall of distorted news serves as criterion and non-traditional news gateways and alternative news media as predictor. 
We will re-run the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and overall news use by using a hierarchical approach in which socio-demographic variables are entered in the first block, traditional news gateways in the second, and non-traditional news gateways and alternative news in the last block. 

Research focus 3: Believe in of distorted news
For exploring differences in distorted as compared to factual news believe and depending on whether the distorted news entailed conspiracy-theoretical elements, we will run a repeated measurement analysis of variance (rANOVA) using headline type (conspirational versus false versus factual) as within-subjects factor. If the main effect of headline type is significant, we will use pairwise t-tests to calculate single comparisons. 
To test H3.1. we will calculate the correlation between participants recall of distorted news and whether participants believe in them.  

To test H.3.2 – H.3.4, we will run a hierarchical regression analysis in which belief in distorted news serves as criterion. Block 1 will entail the unconditional effect of exposure to distorted news, Block 2 the unconditional effects of conspiracy mentality, RWA, and media trust, and Block 3 the interactions between exposure the other three. We will rerun the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and alternative and non-traditional news gateways in two preceding blocks.

Research focus 4: Amplification intentions and pollution behavior
To test H 4.1 - H. 4.6 we will run three hierarchical linear regression analyses: One using amplification intentions for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news as criterion, one using distorted news without conspiracy elements as criterion, and the last one using polluting behavior as criterion. In all three analyses, the believe in the respective distorted news will be entered in Block 1, conspiracy mentality, authoritarianism and in Block 2, and alternative news media use in Block 3. We will repeat the analyses controlling for socio-demographics and political attitude

Research focus 5: Believing in distorted news and behavior
To test H 5.1. and H 5.2. we will calculate zero-correlations between the believe in distorted news and healthy as well as dysfunctional behavior. 
Research focus 6: Indirect effects of distorted news on behavior
If Hypotheses 5.1 and 5.2 are confirmed, we will proceed with testing H.6.1 and H.6.2. 

Research focus 6: Indirect effects
To test H 6.1 and H 6.2 we will calculate two mediation models in which exposure to distorted news serves as predictor, healthy respectively dysfunctional behavior as outcome and believability of distorted news as mediator. We will explore the role of conspirational elements by re-calculating this analysis separating between distorted news with and without conspiracy-theoretical elements. 
As H3.2 – H3.4 predicted that the relationship between exposure to distorted news and their believability will be moderated by conspiracy mentality, RWA, and trust, we will calculate moderated mediation models combining the two mediation analyses with these moderators.

q18.value: Aggregation and dummy-coding is described in the measurement sections. In case of different scale levels or interaction terms in regression analysis, parametric variables will be mean-centered.

q19.value: We will use the standard alpha = .05 and p-values to determine statistical significance. Multiple analyses will be Bonferroni-corrected. We will use two-tailed testing. We will report effect sizes whenever appropriate.

q20.value: We will exclude participants that ask us to so in the quality check variable (“my data should not be used”) and we do not count participants that finished the questionnaire in less than 5 minutes (average processing time is 15 min). As outliers can heavily impact regression models, we will further check for outliers before the analyses. In case of influential outliers, we will rerun the model with and without the influential cases and report effects on the results.

q21.value: We will impute missing values that are missing completely at random or missing at random using the MissForest algorithm (Stekhoven & Buhlmann, 2012). Missing values not at random will be discussed as limitation in the paper.

q23.value:
Please note that there is a related but separate project using the same data by Lara Kuhlfeldt. It can be found in the osf project uncertainty and conspiracy theories.

H.2.2. Using alternative news media is associated with a larger exposure to distorted news about COVID-19.
Research focus 3 (R3): Who believes in distorted news about COVID-19?
RQ 3.1) How credible are distorted as compared to factual news about COVID-19? 
H3.1. People who have seen distorted news before, assign them a higher believability (Pennycook et al., 2017)
H.3.2 Conspiracy mentality will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People scoring higher on conspiracy mentality will belief more in distorted news (Halpern et al., 2019). 
H.3.3 RWA will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People scoring higher on RWA will belief more in distorted news (Frischlich et al. under review)
H3.4 Media trust will moderate the relationship between exposure to and belief in distorted news. People who trust the (mainstream) media belief less in distorted news (Zimmermann & Kohring, 2020). 
Research focus 4 (R4): Who amplifies distorted news about COVID-19?
H 4.1. Higher believe in distorted news predicts higher amplification intentions. 
H 4.2 Higher believe in of distorted news predicts more ‘infodemic’ behavior.  
H 4.3. Participants report higher amplification intentions for distorted news that match their attitudes. 
1.	Higher levels of conspiracy mentality predict higher amplifications intentions for distorted news. 
2.	This association is stronger for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news compared to distorted news without conspiracy-theoretical elements.  
3.	Higher levels of right-wing authoritarianism (RWA) predict higher amplification intentions for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news. 
4.	Lower levels of media trust predict higher amplification intentions for distorted news with and without conspiracy theoretical elements.
H 4.3. Distrustful participants report more pollution behaviors. 
1.	Higher levels of conspiracy mentality predict more infodemic behaviors.
2.	Lower levels of trust predict more infodemic behaviors.
H 4.3. Users of alternative news media report higher amplification intentions for distorted news about COVID-19. 
H 4.3 Users of alternative news media report more ‘infodemic’ behaviors. 
Research focus 5: Behavioral consequences of the believe in distorted news about COVID-19.
H.5.1: Believe in distorted news will be associated negatively with healthy behavior.
H.5.2: Believe in of distorted news will be associated positively with dysfunctional behavior.
Research Focus 6 (R6): Indirect Effects of the Exposure to Distorted News on Behavior
H 6.1 We expect that the relationships between exposure and healthy behavior will be mediated by the believability of distorted news (indirect effect)
H 6.2 We expect that the relationships between exposure and dysfunctional behavior will be mediated by the believability of distorted news (indirect effect).

registration_responses.q6.question: The study employs a unifactorial within-subjects design with four levels (news type: factual, distorted(medical), distorted(conspirational), placebo).
registration_responses.q10.question: Data collection will be conducted via the online access panel by Rispondi. The data is representative for the German population between 18 and 89 in terms of age, gender, and German region. Participants are payed for their participation following the Rispondi guidelines.
registration_responses.q14.question:
We created a set of 11 news headlines: Six of them were distorted news and had been officially debunked by German fact-checking organizations or scientific publications. Three of this distorted news headlines promote conspiracy-theories (“US-special forces use Corona as a distraction to contract their troops at European airports for a secret invasion”, “Corona: A plot to fight overpopulation”, and “Corona-virus: Secret plan of the government detected”), the other three promote false medical information: “Anti-Corona: When taking in, chlorine oxide helps”, “toilet paper from China: Contaminated with corona”, and “Cocaine helps against the corona-virus”). 
Another three headlines were published news by a large-scale German newspaper, Spiegel online. They were selected to refer to societal consequences of the virus (“Epidemiologists recommend long-term restrictions of public life”, “Italy prolongs curfew”, and “Because of the pandemic: US president Trump wants to activate war-economy law”).
Finally, we also included two placebo headlines to account for false memory effects (Allcott & Gentzkow, 2017; Zimmermann & Kohring, 2020). The two placebo headlines reflected both medical (“Dr. Spitzer: Fight corona with kale”) and conspiracy-theoretical (“Corona: “China’s attempt to restrict European civil rights”) ideas. Order of headlines was randomized.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Socio-demographic data: 
o	Current German federal state in which the person lives
o	gender (male, female, diverse)
o	age
o	whether German was the participants’ first language (yes/no)
o	Which educational level they had completed
•	Political leaning (1=”right-wing”, 10=”left-wing”, see Wasmer et al. (1996)). 
Media use:
•	Traditional news gateways used in the last week (Newman et al., 2019): TV, radio, print (weekly- or daily newspaper), online broadcasters, and online newspapers. Multiple answers were possible.
•	Non-traditional news gateways: From the Reuters digital news report (Newman et al., 2019): Social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter), other online news. In addition: Self-developed items tackling “Instant messengers (like WhatsApp/Telegram/Facebook Messenger)”, “YouTube”, “People I know personally (e.g. friends and family)”, “groups within social networks”, and “podcasts”. Multiple answers were possible. 
•	Intentional news avoidance: “I avoid the active consumption of news” (Skovsgaard & Andersen, 2020). 
•	Alternative news media use: Relying on the Reuters digital news survey (Newman et al., 2019), we asked participants which alternative news sources they had used in the last week. As we aimed of balance in terms of political leaning of the outlets, participants reported for six outlets whether they had used them in the last week: Indy media and Junge Welt as left-leaning sources, Politically incorrect news (PI-news), and Junge Freiheit as right-wing leaning sources, Russia today and epoch times as sources with foreign roots. Furthermore, we asked for “other” alternative news sources and participants were able to state that they did not use any ‘alternative news source’. Multiple answers were possible. 
•	Covid-19 news. In the next step, we asked participants for their main news source for information about “the corona-virus”.  The items were largely the same as for news sources, but we added options for “alternative news sources (e.g. PI-news, Indymedia, RT)”, “official sources (e.g. ministries, the Robert-Koch Institute)”, as well as one attention item “I did not witness news about the corona-virus”, and one miscellaneous option. Here, only one option could be selected. 
Trust
•	We measured trust in the established or ‘mainstream’ media with three items, (“The established media report in a balanced manner”, “the reports of the established media are precise”, “the established media depict events fully”) created by Blöbaum (2018) and answered on a 5-point scale (1= “not applying”, 5 = “fully applying”).
•	We measured trust in the political system with two self-created questions: “How much do you trust the German government in handling the current situation around the corona-virus?” and “how much do you trust the health-politic of your country to deal with the corona virus SARS-CoV-2?” – both answered on a 5-point scale (1= “not at all”, 5 = “very much”).
Personal involvement
•	To account for recipients personal involvement with the corona-pandemic, we asked whether they or a close-other belonged to a risk-group following the guidelines by the German Robert-Koch institute (yes, no, I don’t want to answer), and whether they were in personal contact with the virus by asking them whether they were “tested positively for the virus”, “were in official quarantine due to the corona-virus”, or “whether a close other had been tested positively”. Multiple answers were possible. 
Uncertainty due to Corona
•	We measured corona-related uncertainty with a single item: “I feel uncertain due to the current situation related to the corona-virus” (1 = “fully disagree”, 5 = “fully agree”). 
 
Response to the news headlines
•	After each headline, participants rated its familiarity, believability and their amplification intentions. All items were answered on 5-point scales (1 = “absolutely not applying”, 5 = “fully applying”)
•	Familiarity was measured via a single recall statement: “I remember that I have seen this news or have discussed about this news”.
•	Believability was measured with two items: “This news is credible” and “This news is certainly true”. 
•	Amplification intentions were measured with three items: “I would evaluate this news with a ‘like’”, “I would forward this news”, and “I would like to know more about this news”
Corona-motivated behavior
•	Healthy behavior: Three of the behaviors reflected recommendations by the World-health organization and the German Robert-Koch institute (“I have washed or disinfected my hand and/or objects mor often”, “I have cancelled a meeting with friends at home”, and “I have physically distanced from people, I usually shake hands with or hug”).
•	Dysfunctional behavior was measured with two items: “I have bought more supplies than usual”, and “I thought to myself: Now more than ever: Better sick now before intensive care units are overburdened” 
•	‘infodemic behavior’: was measured with two items: “I doubted the ‘mainstream’ media reports”, “I forwarded WhatsApp messages where I did not know the original sender in person”.
For all behaviors, participants were asked how often they executed them due to the “corona-pandemic” (1 = ”never”, 5 = “always”).
 
Attitudes
•	We measured RWA with the nine-item scale by Beierlein et al. (2014). 
•	We measured Conspiracy mentality with the 5-item scale by Bruder et al. (2013)
Personality
•	We measured intolerance for uncertainty with 9-items by Carleton et al. (2007). 
Self-estimated quality/data retraction option
To allow for data retraction, we included a self-estimated quality question. Participants were asked to select between “I have answered the questionnaire as good as possible, although I might have been uncertain once in a while. My data can be used” versus “I answered the questionnaire only for interest, my data should not be used”.
registration_responses.q16.question:
•	Socio-demographics: We will calculate dummy-coded variables representing male gender, residence in the former Eastern versus Western-parts of Germany and higher-education (corresponding to high-school and higher). 
•	Political extremity: We will calculate a variable representing extremity of political attitudes be recoding a political leaning of 5 and 6 as zero, and political-leanings of 4 and 7 as 1, of 3 and 8 as 2, of 2 and 9 as 3, of 1 and 10 as 4, respectively.
•	Media use: To represent traditional news gateways, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the traditional news sources in the last week. To represent non-traditional news gateways, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the non-traditional news sources in the last week. To represent alternative news use, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants used any of the alternative news (including “other alternative news”) in the last week. To represent “dark social” use, we will calculate a dummy- variable representing whether participants accessed news via Instant messengers, social media groups, or family and friends. 
•	Personal involvement: We will calculate a dummy-coded variable representing whether participants have a direct involvement (being either a risk-group, quarantined or infected) or a secondary involvement (a close other being a risk-group or infected). No involvement will serve as reference category
•	Response to the news stimuli: We will calculate means per headline and scale (believe in news headlines, amplification intentions). We will further calculate means per item across the three distorted conspiracy-theoretical headlines, the three false but not conspiracy-theoretical headlines, the two placebo headlines and the three real-headlines and calculate an aggregation of these items per headline type. 
•	Recall of distorted, placebo, and factual news: Following the procedure by Zimmermann and Kohring (2020), we will calculate dummy-variables representing the recall of distorted, real, and placebo news. 
•	Susceptibility factors: Conspiracy mentality, intolerance for uncertainty, and RWA will be aggregated to mean values after checking their internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha). 
•	Behaviors. Depending on the normality of the distribution, we will either calculate means or medians to aggregate the three healthy behaviors, the two dysfunctional behaviors and the two pollution behaviors.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Research focus 1:
 Alternative and non-traditional news use during the pandemic
For testing H 1.1 – H 1.5 we will calculate two logistic regression analyses using (a) the dummy-coded use of alternative news sources and (b) dummy-coded non-traditional news gateways. In these analyses, RWA; conspiracy mentality, political extremity and trust will serve as predictors. We will enter all susceptibility variables simultaneously. We will re-run the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and overall news use by using a hierarchical approach in which socio-demographic variables are entered in the first block, traditional news gateways in the second, and susceptibility variables in the last block. 

Research focus 2: Exposure to distorted news
For testing H.2.1 and H.2.2., we will calculate a linear regression in which recall of distorted news serves as criterion and non-traditional news gateways and alternative news media as predictor. 
We will re-run the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and overall news use by using a hierarchical approach in which socio-demographic variables are entered in the first block, traditional news gateways in the second, and non-traditional news gateways and alternative news in the last block. 

Research focus 3: Believe in of distorted news
For exploring differences in distorted as compared to factual news believe and depending on whether the distorted news entailed conspiracy-theoretical elements, we will run a repeated measurement analysis of variance (rANOVA) using headline type (conspirational versus false versus factual) as within-subjects factor. If the main effect of headline type is significant, we will use pairwise t-tests to calculate single comparisons. 
To test H3.1. we will calculate the correlation between participants recall of distorted news and whether participants believe in them.  

To test H.3.2 – H.3.4, we will run a hierarchical regression analysis in which belief in distorted news serves as criterion. Block 1 will entail the unconditional effect of exposure to distorted news, Block 2 the unconditional effects of conspiracy mentality, RWA, and media trust, and Block 3 the interactions between exposure the other three. We will rerun the analysis controlling for socio-demographic variables and alternative and non-traditional news gateways in two preceding blocks.

Research focus 4: Amplification intentions and pollution behavior
To test H 4.1 - H. 4.6 we will run three hierarchical linear regression analyses: One using amplification intentions for conspiracy-theoretical distorted news as criterion, one using distorted news without conspiracy elements as criterion, and the last one using polluting behavior as criterion. In all three analyses, the believe in the respective distorted news will be entered in Block 1, conspiracy mentality, authoritarianism and in Block 2, and alternative news media use in Block 3. We will repeat the analyses controlling for socio-demographics and political attitude

Research focus 5: Believing in distorted news and behavior
To test H 5.1. and H 5.2. we will calculate zero-correlations between the believe in distorted news and healthy as well as dysfunctional behavior. 
Research focus 6: Indirect effects of distorted news on behavior
If Hypotheses 5.1 and 5.2 are confirmed, we will proceed with testing H.6.1 and H.6.2. 

Research focus 6: Indirect effects
To test H 6.1 and H 6.2 we will calculate two mediation models in which exposure to distorted news serves as predictor, healthy respectively dysfunctional behavior as outcome and believability of distorted news as mediator. We will explore the role of conspirational elements by re-calculating this analysis separating between distorted news with and without conspiracy-theoretical elements. 
As H3.2 – H3.4 predicted that the relationship between exposure to distorted news and their believability will be moderated by conspiracy mentality, RWA, and trust, we will calculate moderated mediation models combining the two mediation analyses with these moderators.

attributes.title: Personal and national future thinking during the COVID 19 pandemic
attributes.description: This research aims to investigate the effects of the COVID 19 pandemic on people's personal and national future thinking. The pandemic creates a unique situation in which the personal and the national intersects much more than before. Specifically, we are interested to see whether the valence based dissociation found between personal and national future thinking (Shrikanth & Szpunar, 2018) would be attenuated due to this unique situation.

q2.value:
1. We expect a main effect of domain. People will write more responses for the personal task compared to the national task.
2. We expect a main effect of valence. People will write more responses to the positive prompt compared to the negative prompt.
3. We expect a domain X valence interaction. In general participants will write more responses for the positive prompts compared to negative prompts for the personal domain whereas they will write more responses to the negative prompts compared to positive prompts for the national domain.
4. We expect a domain X valence X time interaction. We expect the effect above to be attenuated for responses written for 1 month into the past and future. Thus the dissociation between the personal and national domains will decrease when the time-frame covers the last and next 1 month. 
5. In the personal domain, the number of positive responses will be correlated with perceived self-agency and the number of negative responses will be negatively correlated with perceived self-agency.
6. In the national domain the number of positive responses will be correlated with perceived self-, group-, and government- agency and the number of negative responses will be negatively correlated with perceived self-, group-, and government- agency.
7. In the national domain the number of positive responses will be correlated with the general group agency measure and the number of negative responses will be negatively correlated with the general group agency measure.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within subjects design 2 (Domain: Personal, National) X 2 (Valence: Positive, Negative) X 2 (Temporal direction: Past, Future) X 2 (Time: 1 month, 6 months)

q7.value:
The order of presentation for past national, future national, past personal, future personal blocks is random. Within each block the order of presentation for positive vs negative and 1 month vs 6 month blocks is random. 
The same randomization process is applied to the agency evaluations of responses.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study will be web-based. We will use the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform to collect data, and Qualtrics to design the survey. We have 2 main inclusion criteria: to be at least 18 years of age and to be a US citizen.
Since this is online study we will have 6 attention checks throughout the study. Participants who fail in more than 2 attention checks will be excluded from the sample.

q11.value: We are planning to collect data form 200 participants.

q12.value:
We used the G*Power program to determine the necessary sample size. We used Shrikanth & Szpunar (2018)’s study as a basis of our sample size determination. In their Experiment 2 the partial eta square for the domain by valence by time interaction was 0.23. We used that to determine our effect size (f) and the G*Power program gave us an effect size of 0.55. For an effect size of 0.55 and a power of 0.95, the sample size needed is 9. 

In our research, we will not only investigate future thinking but also measure people’s personal and national memories. We also aim to conduct this study longitudinally. Considering the drop-out rate and the people who will be eliminated due to attention checks, we decided a priori to collect data from 200 participants.

question.value: N/A

1. Personal memory - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that happened in their lives 1 month ago and 6 months ago. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
2. National memory - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that happened in the United States 1 month ago and 6 months ago. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
3. Personal future - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that might happen in their lives in 1 month  and in 6 months. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
4. National future - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that might happen in the United States in 1 month  and in 6 months. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
5. Perceived agency - After they complete the tasks above, the first 3 responses they gave for each prompt will appear on the screen and they will be asked to make evaluations about perceived agency. The agency questions will tap perceived agency attributed to circumstances, self, US government, and America as a nation. 
6. Next, they will decide whether their first 3 responses for each prompt is related to the Covid-19 pandemic or not.
7. Past & Future thinking - They will evaluate whether they think about the past, present, future more or less than before.
8. Covid 19 - There will be a section in which they answer questions about the Coronavirus. They will evaluate their feelings during the pandemic, their social distancing practices, communication and media use, and agency attributed to different entities (themselves, US government, America as a nation, circumstances) for the spread of the disease. 
9. Control questions - We will ask whether they or someone they know are infected/died of coronavirus. 
10. Group measures - We included two scales that measure entitativity and group agency. 
11. Political identification - We will ask the political party they identify with, whom they voted for in 2016 and will vote for in 2020 and political ideology (Liberal - Conservative).
12. Demographics
N/A

For the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th hypotheses we will use the following model 2 (Domain: Personal, National) X 2 (Valence: Positive, Negative) X 2 (Temporal direction: Past, Future) X 2 (Time: 1 month, 6 months) repeated measures ANOVA
For the 5th, 6th, and 7th hypotheses we will use the Pearson Correlation

registration_responses.q12:
We used the G*Power program to determine the necessary sample size. We used Shrikanth & Szpunar (2018)’s study as a basis of our sample size determination. In their Experiment 2 the partial eta square for the domain by valence by time interaction was 0.23. We used that to determine our effect size (f) and the G*Power program gave us an effect size of 0.55. For an effect size of 0.55 and a power of 0.95, the sample size needed is 9. 

In our research, we will not only investigate future thinking but also measure people’s personal and national memories. We also aim to conduct this study longitudinally. Considering the drop-out rate and the people who will be eliminated due to attention checks, we decided a priori to collect data from 200 participants.
registration_responses.q20: We will have 6 attention checks throughout the survey. Participants who fail in more than 2 attention checks will be excluded before conducting any analyses.
registration_responses.q6.question: Within subjects design 2 (Domain: Personal, National) X 2 (Valence: Positive, Negative) X 2 (Temporal direction: Past, Future) X 2 (Time: 1 month, 6 months)
registration_responses.q10.question:
This study will be web-based. We will use the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform to collect data, and Qualtrics to design the survey. We have 2 main inclusion criteria: to be at least 18 years of age and to be a US citizen.
Since this is online study we will have 6 attention checks throughout the study. Participants who fail in more than 2 attention checks will be excluded from the sample.
registration_responses.q14.question: N/A
registration_responses.q15.question:
1. Personal memory - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that happened in their lives 1 month ago and 6 months ago. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
2. National memory - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that happened in the United States 1 month ago and 6 months ago. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
3. Personal future - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that might happen in their lives in 1 month  and in 6 months. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
4. National future - We will ask participants to list as many positive and negative things as possible that might happen in the United States in 1 month  and in 6 months. For each prompt they will be given 1 min. 
5. Perceived agency - After they complete the tasks above, the first 3 responses they gave for each prompt will appear on the screen and they will be asked to make evaluations about perceived agency. The agency questions will tap perceived agency attributed to circumstances, self, US government, and America as a nation. 
6. Next, they will decide whether their first 3 responses for each prompt is related to the Covid-19 pandemic or not.
7. Past & Future thinking - They will evaluate whether they think about the past, present, future more or less than before.
8. Covid 19 - There will be a section in which they answer questions about the Coronavirus. They will evaluate their feelings during the pandemic, their social distancing practices, communication and media use, and agency attributed to different entities (themselves, US government, America as a nation, circumstances) for the spread of the disease. 
9. Control questions - We will ask whether they or someone they know are infected/died of coronavirus. 
10. Group measures - We included two scales that measure entitativity and group agency. 
11. Political identification - We will ask the political party they identify with, whom they voted for in 2016 and will vote for in 2020 and political ideology (Liberal - Conservative).
12. Demographics

registration_responses.q17.question:
For the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th hypotheses we will use the following model 2 (Domain: Personal, National) X 2 (Valence: Positive, Negative) X 2 (Temporal direction: Past, Future) X 2 (Time: 1 month, 6 months) repeated measures ANOVA
For the 5th, 6th, and 7th hypotheses we will use the Pearson Correlation

attributes.title: Honesty in coin flipping tasks
attributes.description: A task in economics to assess cheating is the “coin flip” or “die rolling” task.  Participants are asked to flip a coin (or roll a die), and they are paid for the reported number of Heads (or Tails) flipped or the die roll outcome.  Because the outcome of the coin flip(s) or die roll are private and known only to the subject, experimentalists use the statistical properties of a fair coin flip (e.g., 50% of the flips should be Heads and 50% Tails) to identify whether a sample of subjects is cheating—a sample reporting statistically higher numbers of Heads than 50% is deemed to be cheating.  This project seeks to test whether the addition of response times and coin flip order will enrich the predictive capacity of the coin flip task at validating whether dishonesty is occurring in the task.  We propose to test this by examining the likelihood of reported coin flips, the likelihood of the actual ordering of reported flips, and the response times of reported flips in a series of lab and online experiments.

q2.value:
Our hypothesis remains the same as the original pre registration for this project.  Because the "online" condition of the mTurk sample changes not only the online characteristic of our sample (relative to in-lab at our institution) but also the subject pool (drawing from Amazon's mTurk rather than our institution's experimental economics database), we are adding a Fixed and Variable Pay treatment of the online condition that will draw from our institution's ORSEE-database subject pool.  This is the same subject pool from which we drew our in-lab participants previously.  
We hypothesize that the increased "social distance" of going from in-lab to online will increase the number of HEADS reported (statistical dishonesty), and we also hypothesize that it will increase the unlikeliness of the coin flip sequence reported

We will be using same ORSEE subject pool as was used for our original in-lab treatments and, though subjects are not observed during online decisions they are not "anonymous" as they are on mTurk because we know their names from the recruitment process (and they know this), and so we are hypothesizing that the increased social distance will increase the incidence of likely dishonest outcome reports.  This is slightly different than our initial hypothesis that the increase in "anonymity" would increase dishonesty in coin flip outcomes reported.  The change from in-lab to mTurk increases both social distance and anonymity, we are introducing these two new treatments to more cleanly separate social distance (in-lab to online using same subject pool), from the anonymity (as mTurk also is more anonymous than using subjects from the investigators' experimental subject pool) 

Because our new treatments will add social distance, but not the same level of anonymity as is added with the mTurk treatments, that we hypothesis the same directional outcomes going from in-lab to online lab subject, but an even greater impact going from in-lab to mTurk.  We also predict increased statistical cheating when going from lab-subjects-online to mTurk-online because this adds additional social distance as well as anonymity.

So, our modified hypotheses (borrowing from the original registration of this study) would be:
H1: Statistical cheating is more prevalent in the ORSEE-online vs. ORSEE in-lab treatments, and more prevalent in the mTurk (more anonymous) online vs ORSEE-online treatment when variable payments are used (i.e., where temptation to be dishonest exists)
H2:  Statistical cheating is more prevalent when the marginal incentive to cheat is positive (i.e., with our new treatments we anticipate more statistical cheating in the ORSEE-online-Incentives treatment compared to the ORSEE-online-Fixed payment treatment)
H3:  Response time will be faster when social distance and anonymity increases (e.g., now this hypothesizes faster RTs in mTurk compared to ORSEE-online subject treatments, but we also hypothesize faster RTs in ORSEE-online treatments compared to ORSEE-in-Lab treatments)
H4:  Statistically less likely sequences of coin flips will be reported when the incentive to cheat is positive and when social distance and anonymity are increased.  That is, less likely flip sequences in mTurk compared to ORSEE-online treatments, but also less likely flip sequences in ORSEE-online compared with ORSEE-in-Lab)

q7.value: Simple.....subjects recruited for each new treatment are essentially randomly sorting themselves into the two new treatments.

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q9.value: Existing data already exists on the previous 4 treatments we have conducted.  We have not yet collected the data on the new treatments we are describing in this new registration, and so we cannot be aware of any pattern of results with our existing treatment data and these data that have yet to be collected.

question.value:
Data will be collected from the experimental economic database at the investigators' institution just as they were for the in-lab treatments of the previous registration of this study.  Eligibility conditions are the same, but we will NOT recruit any participant who participated in our previous in-lab sessions at our institution.
The collection of data will then follow the process described previously, where the task is administered through the same Qualtrics survey platform as previously used.  We only change the survey to elicit email (instead of mTurk ID) so that participants can be paid via Amazon gift code.

q11.value: We will collect 100 observations on each of the two new treatment conditions (recruiting 110 to account for unusable data or participants who fail the poison pill question).

q12.value: Consistency with the previous treatment sample size

q13.value: We should have full control, but in the even we find it difficult to recruit another 200 participants from our institutions experimental economics subject pool (we already recruited in Fall 2019 about 220, and our total participant pool may be around 800), then we will administer the experiment to as many participants as possible.
